content:
Sure, here is a Linux lab exercise with 30 questions where students can try each command and state its function:

1. What command displays the current working directory?
2. What command allows you to change your current directory?
3. What command lists the contents of the current directory?
4. What command creates a new directory?
5. What command creates a new file?
6. What command deletes a file?
7. What command moves or renames a file?
8. What command copies a file?
9. What command prints text or variables to the standard output?
10. What command displays the contents of a file?
11. What command searches for files in a directory hierarchy?
12. What command displays the manual page for a command?
13. What command compresses files or directories?
14. What command extracts files or directories from an archive?
15. What command displays the file type of a file?
16. What command displays the file permissions of a file?
17. What command changes the ownership of a file?
18. What command changes the group ownership of a file?
19. What command sets the permissions of a file or directory?
20. What command displays the processes running on the system?
21. What command kills a running process?
22. What command displays the system information?
23. What command displays the disk space usage of a file system?
24. What command displays the free and used memory in the system?
25. What command displays the network interfaces and their configuration?
26. What command displays the routing table of the system?
27. What command displays the hostname of the system?
28. What command sets the hostname of the system?
29. What command updates the package index of the system?
30. What command installs a package on the system?

Lab exercise:

1. Type "pwd" to display the current working directory.
2. Type "cd /home/user/Documents" to change to the Documents directory.
3. Type "ls" to list the contents of the current directory.
4. Type "mkdir new\_directory" to create a new directory called "new\_directory".
5. Type "touch new\_file.txt" to create a new file called "new\_file.txt".
6. Type "rm new\_file.txt" to delete the "new\_file.txt" file.
7. Type "mv file1.txt /home/user/Desktop" to move the "file1.txt" file to the Desktop directory.
8. Type "cp file1.txt file2.txt /home/user/Desktop" to copy the "file1.txt" and "file2.txt" files to the Desktop directory.
9. Type "echo Hello World!" to print "Hello World!" to the standard output.
10. Type "cat file1.txt" to display the contents of the "file1.txt" file.
11. Type "find /home/user/Documents -name file1.txt" to search for the "file1.txt" file in the "Documents" directory.
12. Type "man ls" to display the manual page for the "ls" command.
13. Type "tar -cvzf archive.tar.gz file1.txt file2.txt" to compress the "file1.txt" and "file2.txt" files into an archive called "archive.tar.gz".
14. Type "tar -xvzf archive.tar.gz" to extract the files from the "archive.tar.gz" archive.
15. Type "file file1.txt" to display the file type of the "file1.txt" file.
16. Type "ls -l file1.txt" to display the file permissions of the "file1.txt" file.
17. Type "chown user file1.txt" to change the ownership of the "file1.txt" file to the "user" user.
18.
